title-group.article-title: Episodic memory and inhibitory control in people who inject substances results of cohort COSINUS study

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Cognitive disorders associated with addictive disorders are well established in the literature for numerous substances and behaviours. Very few studies have examined the effect of polydrug use on cognitive functioning. These studies have focused on the cognitive effect of one substance among others in very small samples. They did not take into account HCV/HIV infections, which are highly prevalent among polydrug users due to frequent injections and sharing of materials and whose impact on cognition is well documented. In our study, we aim to investigate two critical cognitive functions in the addiction process, memory and inhibitory control, in a population of people who inject substances (PWIS).

sec.title: Method
sec.p: Thanks to the COSINUS Cohort, we evaluated polydrug use of PWIS, inhibitory control, and memory in 383 PWIS by administering the Go/No-go test and the 5-word test. PWIS were recruited in drug consumption rooms (DCRs) and harm reduction facilities.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: 93% of PWIS are polydrug users. Our findings demonstrate typical effects of substance use on memory, revealing a deficit associated with age, along with risky alcohol and cannabis use, while showing a potential benefit from the use of psychostimulants. We found a positive impact of educational level on impulsivity. PWIS who request job assistance and education training exhibit lower free recall compared to the others. HCV/HIV infections are associated with a negative effect on cognition, but the results are mixed. DCR attendance is associated with a positive effect on both memory and inhibitory control.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our study confirms the importance of screening for cognitive deficits in polydrug users, improving specific treatment for cognitive deficits in PWIS through appropriate mental health care, and encouraging multidisciplinary harm reduction and psychiatry care.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: The impact of addictive disorders on cognition is well established [1–3]. Addiction can be considered as cognitive disorders related to neurobiological impairments. Some cognitive impairments occur as a result of substance intake and withdrawal upon stopping intake. Among the cognitive disorders induced by drugs, two deficits play a role in sustaining drug use: impulsivity and memory deficits [1].

sec.title: Impulsivity and inhibitory control as critical cognitive process in addictive disorders
sec.p: The role of impulsivity and inhibitory control is critical in addiction process [4, 5] to be able to refrain from impulse behaviours towards drug intake and compulsivity. Memory deficits impact individuals’ ability to recover from the negative life events associated with drug use, which are critical factors to engage in care [1, 3]. Although numerous papers describe the specific effects of consuming alcohol, cannabis, psychostimulants, and other drugs, very little research investigates the relationship between chronic polydrug use and cognitive disorders. It might be critical to explore cognitive impact of polydrug use given the proportion of poly users among substance users (a half according to Kedia collaborators [6]) and especially in people who inject substances (PWIS) [7]. Indeed, polydrug use is an important public health issue since it is associated with more substance injections and exposure to HIV and HCV infections [8, 9], with substances overdoses and addictive disorders [10, 11] and decreased cognitive functioning [12].

sec.title: Cognitive impairments in substance use
sec.p: Patients with alcohol use disorder show frequently (50–70%) cognitive disabilities [13, 14]. Besides acute impact of alcohol on cognitive abilities [15], chronic use affects global cognition [16–24] and executive function and specifically working memory and response inhibition [25–32]. For chronic cannabis use, a systematic review realized by Broyd et al. (2016) [33] showed that chronic exposure affects cognition and especially memory with a persistence after 1 year abstinence. Impulsivity seems to be related to the onset of cannabis use and might be found in early-users before 16 yo [33]. Whereas acute intoxication of psychostimulants promote enhanced cognitive abilities, early abstinence is associated with deficits [34]. Cocaine/crack use might be associated with similar neuropsychological deficits of executive function like working memory, decision-making ability, planning and cognitive flexibility in early abstinence [35, 36]. In the same way, early abstinence of metamphetamine use is associated with cognitive alterations and among them executive dysfunction and working memory [37, 38]. Concerning impact of treatments on cognition, Benzodiazepines induce dose dependent anterograde amnesia in case of acute intoxication [39]. A meta-analysis showed an impact of benzodiazepines on cognition especially working memory, with a persistence a long time after withdrawal [40]. Chronic morphine use is frequently used in a context of serious disease associated with pain and heavy treatments, depression, anxiety. All these factors promote cognitive disabilities and it is difficult to separate their effect [41]. Finally, agonist opioid treatments might be associated with better cognitive functioning compared to heroin abuse that impact attention, inhibition and working memory [42]. However, in their review, Pujol et al. (2018) pointed out cognitive deficits in patients on methadone in comparison to abstinent heroin users or healthy subjects and especially impaired executive functions [43]. For buprenorphine, the only significant effect is impact on episodic memory. Patients on buprenorphine show significantly higher performance on working memory and decision making than patients on methadone [43].

In summary, the literature shows specific impacts of each substance use on memory and executive functions but in real life, the majority of substance users associate them leading to a combined impact on cognition.

sec.title: Polydrug use and cognition
sec.p: For instance, Block et al. (2002) compared the academic achievement, verbal memory, and abstraction of 192 stimulant, alcohol, and polydrug users to controls (n = 137) [44]. These authors demonstrated a negative impact of polydrug use on all achievement tests with no improvement even after several months of abstinence. Other studies demonstrated cognitive deficits [45, 46], particularly among cocaine polydrug users who show verbal and visual memory impairments [47]; working memory, episodic memory, and aspects of executive function impairments have been described [48] in ketamine polydrug users; and executive impairments coupled with impaired social and emotional judgement processes have been described in MDMA polydrug users [49]. In all these studies, polydrug users who used cocaine, ketamine, or MDMA were compared to polydrug users who did not use the psychoactive substance of interest and who did not show impairments. These results contributed to improving knowledge in the areas of addiction and cognition.

In summary, the impact of polydrug use seems to depend on substances that are combined with more impairments in case of psychostimulants use. However, some limitations must be considered. First, these studies assessed cognitive disorders in small samples of polydrug users (mainly fewer than 50 participants per group), particularly cognitive deficits induced by one substance among others (ketamine in polydrug users versus polydrug use without ketamine use). Second, participants were tested in laboratory conditions and they were required to refrain from the use of psychoactive drugs for a period of 2 weeks before testing and from the consumption of alcohol on the night before the experimental session.

sec.title: Impact of HIV/HCV infections on cognition
sec.p: Third, it is critical to explore the effect of HCV/HIV infections whose the prevalence is well established in polydrug users due to the sharing of injection equipment [50]. Both of these infections have been shown to have an impact on cognition [51–53]. Studies that explored the impact of HIV/HCV infection in polydrug users were frequently conducted in patients early abstinent or abstinent the day of assessment. For example, one study showed increased performance of working memory in HIV negative compared to HIV positive polydrug users abstinent [54]. Another showed different patterns of working-memory impairments according to sex, substance use and HIV. For authors, working-memory impairment is the signature of the association between HIV positive and polydrug use and women who are VIH + without any history of polydrug use were less impaired at working memory than women with substance use history and men [55]. In another study, authors compared performance in decision making (delay discounting task) in abstinent polydrug users and showed higher discounting rates in HCV positive patients compared to controls and HIV positive patients: higher discounting rates were correlated with higher risk injection practices [56].

In summary, although all these studies reported the cognitive difficulties associated to HIV and HCV and the sex, it is difficult to distinguish cognitive disorders associated to HIV/HCV infections from those related to polydrug use.

To examine cognitive deficits in everyday life and outside of laboratory conditions among people who inject drugs (PWIS), we used the COSINUS Cohort (COhort to identify Structural and INdividual factors associated with drug USe) that recruited and followed 665 PWIS in 4 French cities (Bordeaux, Marseille, Paris, and Strasbourg). In the literature, this population of PWIS exhibited a higher prevalence of polydrug use, HCV infection, and HIV infection [57, 58] than the general population, two infections contributing to global cognitive deficits [51–53]. They mainly live in very precarious conditions that have an impact on cognitive functioning [59] and have limited access to social and medical care. In the present descriptive study, we aim to assess the cognitive function of a large population of PWIS 3 months after their recruitment using validated tests. To this purpose, we have selected two rapid tests to assess impulsivity and memory in non-abstinent multiple substance users who are intolerant of waiting: the 5-word test, frequently used to assess memory in addictive disorders [60], and the Go/No-go test for inhibitory control (inhibitory control is a part of impulsivity which comprises attentional, time, cognitive and motor components [61] assessment regularly used in drug users populations [62–64]).

sec.title: Study
sec.p: This prospective, multisite cohort study enrolled 665 PWIS in four cities (Bordeaux, Marseille, Paris, and Strasbourg) during 18 months from November 2016 to May 2018, including a 12-month follow-up that ended in May 2019. Two groups were recruited: one group of PWIS exposed to DCRs in Paris and Strasbourg, and another group not exposed to DCRs in Bordeaux and Marseille. PWIS were interviewed face-to-face by trained interviewers at baseline as well as at the 3-, 6-, and 12-month follow-up assessments. The interviewers were either psychologists, holders of a Master 2 research degree, or trained in social science or public health. The study protocol was approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB00003888) of the French Institute of Medical Research and Health (opinion number: 14–166). The detailed study design was previously described [65].

sec.title: Population
sec.p: Participants were eligible if they reported having injected illegal substances or prescribed medications (e.g., methadone, buprenorphine, benzodiazepines, morphine sulfates, and oxycodone) at least once during the previous month. They were recruited into either DCR or non-DCR services (harm reduction facilities) after providing informed consent. Additional inclusion criteria included being over 18 years of age and proficiency in French. Participants were provided with compensation in the form of 10 euros worth of service vouchers after each interview.

At 3 months, among 665 drug users, only 430 provided their responses to the tests. Among them, only 383 were able to declare in which state of intoxication they were. This information is necessary to consider the differential effects of drug intoxication, drug craving, and neither intoxication nor craving on cognition.

We selected these individuals, regardless of the psychoactive substance or medication used. However, for different reasons, some participants had difficulty completing the tests. Only 374 PWIS completed the Go/No-go test. For 5-words test, only 365 completed the encoding test, 349 the free recall test, and 345 the free recall test with indices (Figs. 1 and 2).Fig. 1
Observations collected for analyses of Gonogo at M3. The number of participants lost to follow-up and the impossibility for some participants to declare in which state of intoxication they are explains the difference in participants between M0 and M3. Some of them have not completed the testFig. 2
Observations collected for analyses of 5-words test at M3. The number of participants lost to follow-up and the impossibility for some participants to declare in which state of intoxication they are explains the difference in participants between M0 and M3. Some of them had difficulties to complete the test

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: The questionnaire collected information about precariousness, drug use, declared HCV/HIV infection status, harm reduction facilities, and access to social and medical care. The data collection tools were partially derived from an evaluation of the Vancouver Downtown Eastside DCR (Insite) and the Vancouver Injection Drug Users Study [66]. Moreover, cognitive tests for the evaluation of impulsivity and memory abilities, such as the Go/No-go test and the 5-word test derived from MOCA tests regularly used to explore memory abilities in drug users [69, 70], were administered.

sec.title: Outcome and explanatory variables
sec.p: Two variables were used as outcomes to explore impulsivity and memory abilities: the Go/No-go score for impulsivity and the score of the 5-words test [67] assessment for memory abilities.

sec.title: Go/No-go test
sec.p: The Go/No-go test is similar to the Stop-Signal task in that both investigate the ability to inhibit a response [68]. The Go/No-go test is a cognitive task aimed at determining the ability of an individual to inhibit a response deemed inappropriate. When the investigator tap once, patient have to tap once and when he tap twice the patient have to not tap. A trial is done in each condition. The sequence is 1–1-2–1-2–2-2–1-1–2.
Subscore/3.
Scoring: no errors = 3; 1 or 2 errors = 2; more than two errors = 1; participant types the same number of times as the interviewer at least 4 consecutive times = 0.
Repeat 3 times: total score = 9.

The 5-word test or Assessment of Dubois [69]: The 5-word test is quick test (2 min) that consists of having the patient learn a list of 5 words. It is validated for mild cognitive impairment in patients with dementia [70, 71] and cognitive disorders associated with substance use disorder [69, 72].
Have the patient read the list and remember the 5 words (in french): Visage, Velour, Eglise, Marguerite, Rouge.
The patient has to tell the words he just read. Repeat this procedure two more times.
Continue with the questionnaire and ask further questions. The goal is to divert the patient’s attention for 3 to 5 min.
Ask the patient again to cite the 5 words: this is a free delayed recall: Count 1 point for each correct answer.

sec.title: For words not recalled and only these, give indices: This is a deferred recall with an indicator. Count 1 point for each correct answer
sec.p: Two scores were analysed: first, the recall without any indicator (score/5) and, second, the recall with an indicator (score/5).

The explanatory variables were chosen for the following reasons: precariousness, drug use, and declared (non testing performed) HCV/HIV infection status might affect cognitive processes negatively, whereas access to harm reduction facilities and to social and medical care might affect cognitive processes positively.

Cognitive variables and variables of choice were extracted from the M3 questionnaire as a function of their known impact on cognition in different categories as follows: (1) criteria associated with sociodemographic and socioeconomic characteristics: age, gender, education level, type of housing (very stable [living in one’s own house, in a rented home, or at the family’s home], unstable or precarious [living in a hostel or in a friend’s house], very precarious [living on the street or in a car]), employment status, and benefiting from health insurance; (2) criteria associated with drug use: daily substance use during the previous month (heroin, buprenorphine, methadone, morphine, cocaine, crack cocaine, benzodiazepines (BZD), and cannabis) and risky alcohol use (based on the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT)-C score1 ≥ 3 for women and ≥ 4 for men); (3) criteria associated with harm reduction services access: DCR use (DCR use in the previous month and DCR use frequency as follows: never, less than 4 times a month, at least once a week, or everyday), needle exchange program in the previous month, and percentage of injection in DCR in the previous month (four categories as follows: no injection, few corresponding to < 25%, some corresponding to 26–74%, or most corresponding to > 75%); (4) criteria associated with social and medical care: access to vaccination, at least one visit to a general practitioner in the previous 6 months, at least one visit to a psychologist/psychiatrist in the previous 6 months, nursing care programs, vaccinations, access to social rights in the previous month, job assistance or training in the previous month, and sanitation services access in the previous month; (5) criteria associated with infection status: testing and health characteristics, treatments, declared (non testing performed) HIV status as seronegative, seropositive, or not tested, and declared HCV (non testing performed) status as seronegative, previously seropositive but cured, seropositive, or not tested.

To consider the effects of intoxication or withdrawal during the assessment of cognitive tasks in PWIS, we assessed their intoxication state as follows: craving, intoxicated, no response, and away from intoxication.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: To investigate cognitive impairment in PWIS, we selected responses to cognitive tests at the 3-month interview for 383 participants who were able to indicate in which state of intoxication they were. We selected these individuals regardless of the substance they used for consumption.
For Go/No-go test analyses, we considered the global scores of the three assessments, that is, 3 × 3 points = score/9 points.
For 5-word test analyses, we considered the two scores: score of free recall/5 and score of recall with indicator/5.

Statistical analyses were performed with R on the cognitive test results obtained during the cognitive assessment. To compare the impact of explanatory variables (see explanatory variables in paragraph 2 of Outcome and explanatory variables in the method) on cognitive results, we conducted analyses of variance (ANOVAs) and reported these results below. We used intoxication state as a covariate to take into account for its impact on cognitive tests. Indeed, when substance users were assessed, the stage of their addiction was different, sometimes intoxicated or in withdrawal of substances or away from intoxication. As these different stages impact cognitive functioning, it is necessary to consider it in analyses. Although no significant association was observed with the scores of the Go/No-go and 5-word tests at the standard threshold (p < 0.05), an interrogation emerged for the encode score (p < 0.1). Statistical significance is defined as p < 0.05. In the event of a significant interaction following the ANOVA, multiple between-group comparisons are performed using Tukey’s post hoc test, for which statistical significance is also defined as p < 0.05. These analyses are reported in the results section. We also conducted Cohen’f tests to measure the magnitude of the observed effects. As our variables do not follow a normal distribution, we verified our results using a nonparametric two-factor ANOVA with permutations using ANOVA with permutation tests function on R (see the following linkage: https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/lmPerm/versions/2.1.0/topics/aovp).The results are exclusively presented in tables for all cognitive tests and explanatory variables. We decided to exclude age as a covariate considering its weak correlation with the scores results. Only a small correlation was observed with the free recall with indicators (cor = 0.17, p > 0.01).
For analyses dependent variables are: Gonogo score, encode score, free recall score, indice score.

Independent variables are:Age, Gender, Study level, Housing, Employment, Health insurance, Heroin use last month, Heroin daily use, BPN use last month, BPN daily use, MET use last month, MET daily use, MOR use last month, MOR daily use, Cocaine use last month, Cocaine daily use, Crack use last month, Crack daily use, BZD use last month, BZD daily use, Cannabis use last month, Cannabis daily use, Risky alcohol use, DCR use last month, DCR use frequency, Percentage of injections in DCR, General practitioner visit last month, Psychological care last month, Screening tests last month, Vaccination last month, Addiction treatment last month, Access to social rights last month, Job assistance and training last month, Housing assistance last month, Nursing care last month, Access to injection support last month, Needle exchange program last month, Sanitation services access last month, declared HIV status, declared HVC status.

sec.title: Description of the population
sec.p: In this study, PWIS were predominantly male (80.7%), aged over 30 years (83.8%), and unemployed (85.3%). Women were younger than men: respectively a mean of 35.2 years in women vs 40 in men and a median of 33 in women vs 41 in men. The mean age of the total group is 39.1 with a median 39. The majority of them lived in precarious conditions: 41.5% lived in very precarious housing (homeless or temporary shelters) and 22.2% lived in unstable housing. Moreover, 28.2% of PWIS did not have access to health insurance.

The majority of PWIS were polydrug users (93%): nearly half of them (51.2%) used 2 or more different substances during the day, whereas 70.7% used 3 or more different substances during the previous month. Only 7% of PWIS used one substance during the previous month. On average, 1.6 substances were used daily and 3.3 were used monthly. Methadone, morphine, cannabis, cocaine, and crack cocaine were the most commonly used daily and monthly substances. A Kruskal–Wallis test demonstrated a link between age and polydrug use during the month (K(383) = 5.62; p < 0.05). We observed that PWIS aged 45 or more used, on average, fewer substances than younger individuals (3.03 vs. 3.45) (Table 1).Table 1

sec.title: Go/No-go results
sec.p: For all subsequent analyses, we conducted an ANOVA using the Go/No-go score obtained during the 3-month interview for all participants as a function of group (explanatory variable), taking into account the variable intoxication state as a covariate.

We observed a difference in Go/No-go based on the participants’ level of education. PWIS with a high school diploma had higher scores (8.2/9) than those without a high school diploma (7.8/9) (F(1,374) = 7.3; p < 0.01; Cohen’s f = 0.14, IC 95% [0.04, 0.24]). A similar analysis considering Go/No-go score in all participants as a function of declared HIV status and with intoxication state as a covariate indicated that HIV-positive users have a significantly decreased Go/No-go score (F(1,374) = 5.6; p < 0.01; Cohen’s f = 0.17, IC 95% [0.06, 0.27] (VIH Status)). The difference in Go/No-go score between the group that declared being HIV positive (6.9/9) and those that declared being HIV negative (8/9) was 1.1 points.

The same analysis indicated no difference between the group that declared being HCV positive and those who declared being HCV negative, as well as those who declared not being aware of their status and those who reported being cured.

We observed no difference in the Go/No-go score based on age, gender, precariousness, housing assistance, job assistance, employment, access to social rights, frequency of injection, or visits to the DCR (p > 0.05).

sec.title: 5-words test results
sec.p: For all subsequent analyses, we conducted an analysis of variance (ANOVA) using the memory score (encoding, free recall, and recall with indicator) obtained in 3 months interview for all participants as a function of group (explanatory variable), taking into account the variable intoxication state as a covariate.

sec.title: Encoding
sec.p: For these analyses, we conducted an ANOVA on the score of the second repetition of the 5-word test after the reading.
We observed an effect of gender on encoding, with a higher score in women (4.5 words encoded/5) than in men (4.1 words encoded/5) (F(1,365) = 6.4; p < 0.05; Cohen’s f = 0.13, IC 95% [0.03, 0.24]).

We also discovered a difference in the encoding of the 5 words among the different HCV status declared by PWIS (F(3,365) = 4.8; p < 0.01; Cohen’s f = 0.20, IC 95% [0.07, 0.29]). Tukey’s post hoc analyses indicated an effect of the declared HCV status, with a higher score in users who declared a negative status (4.3 words encoded/5) than in those who declared a positive status (3.8 words encoded/5). Additionally, the difference was significant between those who declared not being aware of their status (4.4 words encoded/5) and those who declared being positive (3.8 words encoded/5) (p < 0.05) as well as between users who reported being cured (4.2 words encoded/5) and those who declared being positive (3.8 words encoded/5) (p < 0.05).
We observed no effect of other explanatory variables on encoding (p > 0.05).

sec.title: Free recall
sec.p: We found an effect of daily crack consumption on free recall in users, with (F(1,349) = 17.1; p < 0.001; Cohen’s f = 0.22, IC 95%[0.11, 0.33]a higher score in individuals who use crack cocaine (4.4 words recalled/5) than in those who declared no crack cocaine consumption (3.8 words recalled/5).

Free recall was also found to be associated with cannabis use during the previous month (F(1,349) = 7.7; p < 0.01; Cohen’s f = 0.15, IC 95%[0.04, 0.25]), with lower scores for cannabis users (3.7 words recalled/5) than for nonusers (4.2 words recalled/5).

We observed an effect of DCR attendance at 3 months on free recall (F(1,349) = 13.6; p < 0.001; Cohen’s f = 0.20, IC 95%[0.09, 0.30]). Users who attended DCR had a higher score (4.2 words recalled/5) than those who did not attend (3.7 words recalled/5). Similarly, we observed an effect between those who attended DCR often and those who did not (F(3,344) = 4.8; p < 0.005).

Finally, participating in job assistance and training (F(1,349) = 6.1; p < 0.05) and/or receiving nursing care (F(1,349) = 6.9; p < 0.01; Cohen’s f = 0.13, IC 95%[0.02, 0.24]) during the month was associated with lower scores (3.3/5 vs. 4/5 for no job assistance participation; 3.7/5 vs. 4/5 for no nursing care).
We observed no effect of other explanatory variables on recall (p > 0.05).

sec.title: Free recall with indicators
sec.p: We found an effect of age on free recall with indicators, with a higher score among older users. Users aged over 45 years (4.4 words recalled/5) and between 30 and 44 years (4.1 words recalled/5) achieved higher scores than those under 30 years (3.8 words recalled/5) (F(2,345) = 4.3; p < 0.01; Cohen’s f = 0.19, IC 95%[0.08, 0.30]).

We also observed an effect of daily crack consumption on free recall with indicators in PWIS (F(1,345) = 11.1; p < 0.001, Cohen’s f = 0.18, IC 95%[0.07, 0.29]), with a higher score in individuals who used crack cocaine (4.5 words recalled/5) than in those who declared no crack cocaine consumption (4 words recalled/5).

Cannabis use during the previous month was also associated with a lower free recall with indicators score (4.0 words recalled/5 vs. 4.3 words recalled/5 among nonusers) (F(1,345 = 6.9; p < 0.01; Cohen’s f = 0.14, IC 95%[0.03, 0.25]). The same was observed for risky alcohol use2 (F(1,345) = 4.3; p < 0.05; Cohen’s f = 0.11, IC 95%[0.00, 0.22]), with higher scores among users who did not have this behaviour (4.3 words recalled/5 vs. 4 words recalled/5).

We observed an effect of DCR use at 3 month interview on free recall with indicators (F(1,345) = 17.5; p < 0.001; Cohen’s f = 0.23, IC 95%[0.12, 0.33])). PWIS who attended DCR had a higher score (4.4 words recalled/5) than those who did not attend DCR (3.9 words recalled/5). Similarly, we observed an effect between those who attended DCR often and those who did not (F(3,345) = 5.9; p < 0.001; Cohen’s f = 0.23, IC 95%[0.10, 0.33]).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In summary, our results showed that PWIS were predominantly male in high social precariousness and unemployed. The majority were polydrug users. For inhibition, PWIS with diploma show higher Go/Nogo score. Positive HIV status declared is associated with negative impact on Go/Nogo score whereas no impact for positive HCV status declared was found. For encoding memory, we found a higher score in women compared to men, a negative impact of positive HCV status declared. Free recall with and without is enhanced by cocaine/crack consumption but decrease in case of cannabis use and risky alcohol use. DCR attendance is associated with better free recall with and without indicators, whereas participating to job assistance is associated with lower free recall. Being older is associated with higher score for free recall with indicators. Putting these results into perspective with the literature, our study revealed that 93% of PWIS are polydrug users, thus confirming the findings of previous studies [50]. Additionally, our findings demonstrated less impulsivity in PWIS with a higher level of education. One possible explanation could be that higher educational attainment may necessitate the development of knowledge, skills, motivation, self-esteem, personal disposition, self-control, and executive function and facilitate the development of executive function and inhibitory control [73]. Likewise, PWIS who request job assistance and training demonstrate a lower free recall. These results indicate challenges in mobilising cognitive resources to find a job and are in line with the fact that individuals with memory deficits face greater difficulties in the world of employment, regardless of the disease causing these impairments [74–76]. Similarly, Matthews et al. (2013) found that job seekers with additional drug and alcohol problems reported significant difficulties, particularly with memory and executive function [77]. Moreover, stress related to unemployment had a negative impact on the possibility to quit addiction [78]. This vicious cycle impact negatively PWIS possibilities to find a job and to be socially inserted. Additionally, our findings highlighted differences in encoding memory processing between women and men, and showed that older PWIS exhibited better performance in memory recall, with a significant effect observed for recall with indices. These results are in line with the existing literature which reports differences in memory performance based on sex [79]. However, they may be counterintuitive with regard to the effect of age. One explanation might be that older PWIS consumed fewer products during the previous month than younger PWIS, which might explain the low impact of substances on cognition in older PWIS compared to younger PWIS. In this way, an observational study conducted in 2003 on a cohort of old patients (> 55 yo) followed for 12 months showed that older patients had better substance use and functioning in everyday life than did younger patients [80]. Moreover, PWIS who required nursing care during the previous month faced difficulties in encoding. The life conditions of PWIS are very precarious, and for some of them, particularly those who require nursing care, they suffer from very poor health. As indicated by studies in mental health and older populations [81, 82], poor health is associated with deficits in global cognitive functioning, which may explain our results. Concerning declared HIV and HCV infections, we observed higher impulsivity in PWIS with declared HIV infections but normal performances in PWIS with declared HCV infections. However, we found that declared HCV infections seemed to be associated with an impact on encoding. These alterations confirm results reported in the literature [51–53, 83] but we expected a more pronounced effect. For HCV, the literature indicates that the main domains impacted are executive, memory, attention, and concentration [46]. A majority of HIV patients performs below expectations on formal neurocognitive tests, and these impairments are increased by coinfections and epilepsy [83]. The deficits in individuals with HIV are progressive, comprising neuropathy, dementia, and declining global cognitive function. However, there can be intraindividual variability based on the clinical features of the disease [52, 53]. In this regard, we anticipated a more global cognitive impact of both infections on episodic memory and inhibitory control. However, these results must be considered in light of other factors like substances consumption, access to medical and social cares. First, substance use might improve or damage cognitive functioning. In our study, we showed that crack consumption improves episodic recall with and without indicators. This result is counterintuitive regarding results of Colzato and colleagues (2009) that examined cognitive disorders in polydrug users + cocaine vs polydrug users [46]. In our study, we tested active crackers who were not supposed to stop their use the day before as it was required in their study. The positive impact of crack cocaine on memory we found could be due to acute psychostimulant effect rather than long-term benefit. Moreover, as we compared cognition in polydrug users who use different associations of active substances, with possible sedative effects for some and psychostimulant effect for others, it is possible that this result reflects the differential acute cognitive impact of substances that induces a slowing and a sedation compared to psychostimulant action of crack cocaine. Compared to the literature, the differential impact of crack on memory between studies could be due to the withdrawal associated with cessation of crack cocaine use versus active use. In the literature, the use of crack cocaine may indeed improve cognitive functioning when used before tests [84]. Moreover, our results showed that cannabis use and risky alcohol use decreased free recall. These results are in line of the literature. Long-term or heavy cannabis use is associated with impaired encoding, storage, manipulation, and retrieval mechanisms [85], whereas alcohol use is associated with impairments in working memory, encoding, and consolidation [86, 87]. In our study, we showed no effect of other substances (heroin) or treatments (methadone, buprenorphine, benzodiazepines) whereas they promote cognitive dysfunctions (see above in introduction). These results could be due to psychiatric disorders associated to substance use disorder, i.e. dual diagnosis. Indeed, in PWIS, psychiatric comorbidities are common [88, 89] and they affect global cognition and everyday life functioning. Treatments of addictive disorders should have a positive impact on psychiatric disorders leading to a better global functioning that is not found when someone without any psychiatric disorder taking the same medication. For example, methadone or buprenorphine have an antidepressant and anxiolytic effects that is very interesting as treatment of anxiety and depression and may decrease cognitive impairments in polydrug users with anxiety and depressive disorders compared to those without psychiatric comorbidity [90]. In the same vein, benzodiazepines are a medication prescribed for anxiety that might increase cognitive functioning in substance users with high level of anxiety compared to those without. Two explanations are possible. First, our study did not compare cognition of PWIS to a control group. This comparison might show possible impairments in PWIS. Another explanation is the association of acute effect of psychostimulants with other substances that decrease the visible impact of these products on cognition and make them less visible. For example, a study showed that recreational use of cocaine affects negatively flexibility but not the maintenance of information in WM [39]. Finally, our study explored memory and impulsivity, two critical cognitive abilities in addictive processes among others. It is possible that a deeper exploration will reveal other cognitive difficulties according to the study conducted by Block et al. (2000) [44] who showed in early abstinence period, immediately after stopping their use a poorer total recall but also in abstraction tests. Second, attending DCR seems to improve performance on free recall with and without indicators compared to not attending DCR. In DCR, PWIS have access to healthcare services like psychiatric, somatic, and social services that promote well-being and increase cognitive functioning. Moreover, the possibility to have an access to harm reduction services should decrease stress related to potential infections, to discrimination rejection and the gaze of others and offers them a stable environment where they will be warmly welcomed. In this way, under ecological conditions, it might be challenging to separate the impact of different factors on cognitive functioning in PWIS in everyday life. The majority of the studies on polydrug use explored the impact of one substance on cognition in polydrug users, such as ketamine [48] or MDMA [91]. In these studies, authors identified cognitive deficits related to the substance examined. However, less is reported on the global impact of polydrug use, and no details are provided about the declared HCV/HIV status of people who use drugs. Moreover, the participants in these studies are less likely to live in precarious conditions and have a more occasional use of other substances. As such, the findings obtained in these studies are not directly comparable to our results from the COSINUS study, which must be confirmed with other ecological studies on PWIS. This confirmation might be useful to develop cognitive training and remediation interventions for substance users. In a Delphy consensus study, 54 experts gave recommendations and preferred approaches for cognitive remediation. They recommend to target among others things biases and emotions as well as integrated cognitive skills with validated interventions delivered by neuropsychologists [92]. In out polydrug users, Vall-Serrano and colleagues showed that associate goal-management training and mindfulness improve working memory and executive function like impulsivity and planning [93]. The development of tools more adapted to this population who has difficult to adhere to treatments implementation and have difficulty to take time for them would be necessary.

sec.title: Limits
sec.p: In our study, the tests were administered in four cities by different interviewers, which could influence the results because different interviewers might proceed differently with the cognitive assessment. However, to reduce this bias, the handover procedure was written down and was required to be implemented step by step, and the first author of the paper checked the procedure with the interviewers. Moreover, our findings are limited to episodic memory and inhibitory control. Thus, it would be valuable to assess the global functioning of this vulnerable population using different tests. Finally, we did not examine the impact of psychiatric disorders, such as personality disorders [94], psychosis [95], or depression [96], on the performance of these tests. These comorbidities are widely recognised to impact cognitive functioning and can pose barriers to PWIS’ access to care. As we highlighted in our discussion, dual diagnosis and their medications might affect differentially cognition according to the type of psychiatric disorder and the type of medication. New studies have to explore cognitive disorders in polydrug users with psychiatric comorbidities.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our study explored episodic memory and inhibitory control in PWIS recruited in DCR and harm reduction facilities, a population that is particularly vulnerable and poorly socially integrated, with massive polydrug use of different psychoactive substances. We have demonstrated that declared HIV and HCV positive status have an impact on cognitive functioning, as do social precariousness and low educational levels. Our findings demonstrate typical effects of substance use on memory, revealing a deficit associated with age, along with risky alcohol and cannabis use, while showing a potential benefit from the use of psychostimulants. Overall, our study confirmed the necessity to improve access to cognitive remediation/training to treat cognitive deficits in PWIS through appropriate mental health care and to encourage multidisciplinary harm reduction and psychiatry care.

notes.title: Authors’ contributions
notes.p: The four investigators (MA, MJR, LL and PR) designed the survey and supervised the data collection of the COSINUS cohort. For this paper, statistical analyses were realized by LL in Strasbourg and confirmed by SD and MA under the supervision of MJR and LL. LL wrote the first version of the paper which was firstly discussed with MJR and reviewed by all the authors. All authors contributed to this paper, critically reviewed its content, and approved the final version.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: The project was entirely funded by the Mission Interministérielle de Lutte contre les Addictions (MILDECA).

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: Due to ethical requirements, data set are not available. Please contact the contact author.

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
notes.p: The study protocol was approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB00003888) of the French Institute of Medical Research and Health (opinion number: 14–166).

notes.title: Consent for publication
notes.p: Participants provided oral informed consent and the consent have been signed by the interviewer. In view of the use of illegal substances, the ethics committee has requested that no identifying marks be visible on the consent forms.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
